title: Fireman Sam mascot dropped over concerns character is not inclusive
text: A fire service has axed popular TV character Fireman Sam as its mascot. Lincolnshire Fire and Rescue (LFR) made the decision after it received negative feedback regarding the mascot not being inclusive enough. The character had previously been used by the fire service for station open days and advertising materials. Instead LFR has introduced new mascots in the form of gender-neutral blue, red and yellow fire extinguishers called Freddy, Filbert and Penelope. We’ll tell you what’s true. Chief fire officer Les Britzman said: “Firefighters nationally and residents locally have raised some concerns that ‘Fireman Sam’ doesn’t reflect the fire service today, in terms of both the job itself and our workforce. “It’s important to us that our open days and community events don’t make anyone feel excluded and therefore we took this decision. The 11 most stylish TV characters of all time 1/11 Villanelle from Killing Eve Ever since Killing Eve's Villanelle, played by Jodie Comer, pranced through the streets of Paris in a pink tulle dress designed by Molly Goddard she has become a fashion icon. Villanelle’s bold looks have taken Pinterest by storm, sparking a 1,060 per cent increase in searches year-on-year. Meanwhile, Lyst data shows that following the first episode of the second series there have been over 3,000 searches for “Killing Eve pyjamas”. Alamy Stock Photo 2/11 Sabrina Spellman from Chilling Adventures of Sabrina Sabrina Spellman’s preppy looks have become a huge source of fashion inspiration for many viewers, especially as the colder months approach with searches up 7,450 per cent on Pinterest. On Lyst, demand for ribbed sweaters grew by 49 per cent in April following the release of the show’s second season, while views of Fair Isle sweaters also increased by 30 per cent in the same period. Dean Buscher/Netflix 3/11 Renata Klein from Big Little Lies Lyst and Pinterest revealed the third most influential TV character when it comes to fashion as Renata Klein, played by Laura Dern, from the hit HBO series Big Little Lies. Pinterest saves for the character's outfits have grown by 490 per cent year-on-year, while Lyst states that there was an 87 per cent increase in searches for Roland Mouret’s red zodiac gown after it was seen on the character in the first episode of the show’s second season. Jennifer Clasen/HBO 4/11 Jane Villanueva from Jane the Virgin When satirical telenovela Jane the Virgin launched in 2014, its main character Jane Villanueva captured the attention of fashion fans who wanted to recreate her wearable looks. Pinterest data highlights an 85 per cent increase in searches year-on-year for Villanueva, while Lyst shows that the Zimmermann Heathers mini dress she wore was viewed more than 7,000 times in the week following the release of that episode. CW 5/11 Tan France from Queer Eye Netflix’s reboot of Queer Eye introduced the world to a brand new Fab Five, including British fashion expert Tan France. Known for his love of patterned and striped shirts, France’s style is behind some of this year’s biggest spikes in demand on Lyst. Following the release of the show’s fourth season in March, searches for men’s 'striped shirt' increased by 39 per cent mont-on-month, while views of men’s suits grew by 11 per cent. Furthermore, there were over 10,000 searches on Lyst for patterned polo shirts in the first two weeks of March, with over 100 customers specifically searching for a 'Tan shirt'. Getty Images 6/11 Veronica Lodge from Riverdale Riverdale’s preppy aesthetic has made it a popular source of fashion inspiration since it first hit our screens in 2017. But it is the show's resident 'It' girl, Veronica Lodge, that has really driven fashion searches on Lyst. Worn in the show’s third season, a Topshop checked coat sold out within seven days after appearing on screen. Meanwhile, Pinterest data shows a 29 per cent increase in searches for pleated dresses, a staple in Lodge's wardrobe. Netflix 7/11 Fleabag from Fleabag British comedy-drama Fleabag became a global phenomenon when its second season was released earlier this year. The black backless jumpsuit worn by Phoebe Waller-Bridge’s character in the season two premiere sparked a 460 per cent increase in searches on Pinterest in June, with more than 500 people specifically searching for “Fleabag jumpsuit” on Lyst. Along with a 4,757 per cent increase in searches for Fleabag on Pinterest, Lyst data shows a strong interest in more of the character’s fashion choices with demand for black trench coats and Reformation dresses significantly increasing in April. BBC 8/11 Eric Effiong from Sex Education Sex Education’s Eric Effiong, played by Ncuti Gatwa, has been inspiring viewers with his colourful looks ever since the show aired in January 2019. Since the show's debut, searches for Nike’s PG 2 sneakers grew by 14 per cent between January and March after Eric wore a bright purple pair in an episode. In the same period, demand for matching tracksuits increased by 22 per cent, while his tiger-print sweatshirt sparked a 40 per cent search increase on Lyst. Netflix 9/11 Zoey Johnson from Grown-ish Grown-ish’s Zoey Johnson, played by Yara Shahidi, is one of the most stylish college students on television right now. The show’s second season has been proving particularly inspiring, with searches for the character's outfits up 28 per cent on Pinterest. According to Lyst, Johnson's Lilo Striped Cat jumper by Zadig & Voltaire became the most wanted animal jumper in June, while views of the Diane von Furstenberg leopard-print shirt spiked 15 per cent after being worn on the show. Freeform 10/11 Ava Jalali from Pretty Little Liars: The Perfectionists It might have been just 10 episodes long but Pretty Little Liars: The Perfectionists has still managed to become one of the most stylish TV shows of the year. Fashion student Ava Jalali, played by Sofia Carson, has driven a 9,160 per cent rise in searches on Pinterest, while searches for her ruffled velvet dress increased 37 per cent the week it aired. On Pinterest, saves for images of the character have increased by 28 per cent. Netflix “We always make sure that we include plenty of activities and other ways to engage children and adults, to help them learn more about fire safety and a firefighter’s role.” According to The Lincolnite, an email has been sent to all fire stations in the county requesting that they do not use the Fireman Sam mascot in the future. “Please can you ensure when you are designing posters that Fireman Sam is not used and more inclusive images are utilised,” the email reads. “This includes no longer using the Fireman Sam costumes on stations.” In March this year Fireman Sam faced criticism along with Peppa Pig for encouraging gender stereotypes. London Fire Brigade hit out at Peppa Pig for not using the term ‘firefighter’ in an episode called "The Fire Engine". The service tweeted: “Come on @peppapig, we’ve not been firemen for 30 years. You have a huge influence on kids & using out of date stereotypical gender specific wording prevents young girls from becoming firefighters.” The tweet launched a social media debate, which was highlighted on ITV series Good Morning Britain when host Piers Morgan criticised the issue women have with the use of the word “fireman” in cartoons, including Fireman Sam. “It’s not that women don’t want to go and risk their lives, but actually, it’s cartoons,” Morgan said. “It’s Fireman Sam, that is the problem, because it is called Fireman Sam."
